quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: September and Crusades
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, birds, pilgrims. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: The passenger pigeon was one of the most common birds in the world- it is estimated that there were about five billion in the United States alone. The last passenger pigeon died on September 1, 1914 in this zoo.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Cincinnati Zoo

questions.question: One of the most brutal crusades was the Albigensian Crusade (this is true). The aim of this crusade was to eliminate the religion of the Cathars.
The Fourth Crusade (1202–1204) was called upon by Pope Innocent II and was originally intended to retake Jerusalem by conquering this country.

On September 1, 1985, at a depth of 2 miles (3,8 km), south-east of Newfoundland, the wreck of the Titanic was discovered. Jean-Louis Michel was one of the two people who led the expedition. He was the other one.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Dr. Robert Ballard

questions.question: The second Crusade, launched in 1145, was the most successful of all Crusades.
The military power of the Teutonic Order was broken after the Battle of Grunwald, after a defeat by these two countries.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Poland and Lithuania

questions.question: On September 1, 1979, Pioneer 11 became the first spacecraft to visit Mercury.
Moammar Qaddafi and a group of officers staged a coup detat against King Idris on 1st of  September 1969 (this is true). The coup was unsuccessful and Qaddafi was sent to prison.
The first Crusade was initiated by Emperor Alexius I, when he appealed to Pope Urban II for help in defending against the Muslims.   Alexius I was the ruler of this great empire.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Byzantine Empire

questions.question: On September  1, 1983 Korean Air Flight KAL-007 was shot down after entering Soviet airspace (this is true).   Some of the passengers and crew survived the crash.
On September 1, 1957, this Grammy Award - winning singer was born.  She began her career as lead singer for the Miami Sound Machine.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Gloria Estefan

questions.question: The crusaders considered themselves sort of pilgrims and so, before joining a Crusade, they swore a vow to do this.

options.text: To preach Christianity to Muslim prisoners
To kill at least ten Muslims

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: To successfully reach Jerusalem

questions.question: The Kingdom of Jerusalem was established after the first Crusade.  Godfrey of Bouillon was chosen to be King, but he refused the title and took this one instead.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Defender of the Holy Sepulchre

questions.question: Jews saw the Crusades as great help and welcomed knights as heroes.
On September 1, 2004, in a small Russian town, armed terrorists took hundreds of schoolchildren and adults hostage. What was the name of the town?

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Place and Day
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, summer, world. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Magellan set out on his voyage around the world on this day.
The mass suicide in Jonestown took place on this day in 1978.
In 1799, Napoleon began his campaign to conquer the Ottoman Empire, but was eventually defeated at this city.
One of these events did not take place during December.

options.text: Bush ordered US troops to Somalia
The Prohibition in the US ended

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Napoleon died in exile

questions.question: 1783 Treaty of Paris was signed on this day.
This largest Christian military order was established in the aftermath of the First Crusade and is widely known as this.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Knights Templar

questions.question: One of these events did not take place on a summer day.

options.text: Admiral Nelson was buried at St. Pauls Cathedral
President Adams settled in a new capital

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Admiral Nelson was buried at St. Pauls Cathedral

questions.question: NASA was established in this year, on July 29.
One of these events did not take place on March 19.

options.text: Americas first recorded bank robbery took place
General Fromm was executed for plot against Hitler

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Indira Gandhi led India

questions.question: The Treaty of Brest-Litovsk was signed on March 3, 1918.
The English Navigation Acts were a series of laws which restricted foreign shipping. Resentment against the Navigation Acts was a cause for which war?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Anglo-Dutch Wars

questions.question: The four events in this question took place on  February 4. However, one of the pairs (event - the year in which it happened) is wrong.

options.text: First U.S. helicopter was shot down in Vietnam - 1962
Bank of the U.S. Shut Down - 1841

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Patty Hearst was kidnapped - 1976

questions.question: In the Battle of Gaugamela, 331 B.C. , Alexander the Great of Macedonia defeated which king?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Darius III

questions.question: What precipitated the 1969 six-day war between El Salvador and Honduras?

options.text: Import tariffs on Honduran goods exported into El Salvador
Import tariffs on Salvadoran goods exported into Honduras
Control over the oil reserves in the Gulf of Fonseca

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: A soccer game

questions.question: All of the Crusades were called upon by Popes.

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Battlefield and War
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, heights, country. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: What was the name of the 1989 film, directed by Brian De Palma, in which a Vietnamese girl is kidnapped, raped and murdered by US troops?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Casualties of War

questions.question: In this film, the Vietnam War veteran, played by Roy Scheider experienced a war flashback, involving the execution of an enemy soldier.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Blue Thunder

questions.question: Elkhorn Tavern is located on which battlefield?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Pea Ridge

questions.question: The Maryes Heights are a landmark, found on which battlefield?
In this 751 A.D. military conflict between Islamic forces and Chinese forces, the Chinese were completely defeated.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Talas War

questions.question: Hornets Nest is associated with which battlefield?
The Henry House can be found on which Civil war battlefield?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Bull Run

questions.question: The Great Northern War was the war fought between a coalition of Russia, Denmark-Norway and Saxony-Poland one side and Sweden on the other side. The coalition attacked Sweden in what year?
In this movie the main character experiences a flashback in which he is tied in a crucifying position and being slowly slashed with a large knife.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: First Blood

questions.question: The Burnside Bridge is related to which Civil War battlefield?
What conflict was initiated by a self-proclaimed mystic, named Hong Xiuquan, who claimed that he was the new Messiah?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Taiping Rebellion

questions.question: The Battle of Crécy, which took place on 26 August 1346, was one of the most important battles of a war conflict between which two countries?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: France and England

questions.question: Which country occupied Vietnam from the end of WW II to 1954, setting the scene for a civil war between North and South Vietnam?
F. D. Toussaint Louverture, a freed self-educated slave, was one of the leaders of which uprising?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Haitian Revolt

questions.question: This conflict, which lasted from 1839 to 1842, is regarded as a trade-inspired war between Great Britain and the Qing Empire in China.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The First Opium War

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Mayflower and England
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, field, pilgrims. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Where was the Mule Shoe located?
Before its trans-Atlantic voyage the Mayflower was a merchant ship travelling between England and other European countries. What was its primary cargo?
On what date did the Mayflower leave port?
How wide was the Mayflower estimated to be?
The Crater is a famous landmark, located on which battlefield?
In the 1982 film Airplane 2: The Sequel the space shuttle was called the Mayflower 1.
It is estimated that the crew of the Mayflower consisted of how many people?
Farmland, owned by the McPherson family, the Cordori family, the Spangler family, the Culp family, and the Rose family is part of which battlefield?
Where is the Field of Lost Shoes located?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: New Market

questions.question: How many days did it take the Mayflower to make the crossing from England to America?
On which battlefield was Lookout Mountain a dominant feature?
Where did the pilgrims aboard the Mayflower intend to settle?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: in Virginia

questions.question: What is the Mayflowers estimated length?
How many passengers were aboard the Mayflower when it crossed the Atlantic?
The Mayflower returned to England in 1621.

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Moon and Spacecraft
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, people, independence. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Luna 1 was the first spacecraft to land on the Moon.
Dutch independence from Spain (1648) was recognized in this Treaty.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Treaty of Munster

questions.question: After the Romans left in 412-413 AD present-day Netherlands was populated by the Franks, Saxons and what other tribe?
Neil Armstrong, Edwin Aldrin and Bill Anders were the three astronauts on Apollo 11.
What was the nickname of William, Prince of Orange, Count of Nassau (Willem, Prins van Oranje, Graaf van Nassau), killed in 1584 in the city of Delft?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Silent

questions.question: President Kennedy once said I believe this nation should commit itself to achieving the goal, before this decade is out, of landing a man on the moon and returning him safely to the Earth. This was the goal of the Apollo project. Which one of these rockets was used to launch the Apollo spacecraft?

The project of the Soviet Union, that aimed at the Moon, was the Luna programme. Although all of the Luna missions were unmanned, they were pioneers in many space explorations. Which one of these missions was the first to take pictures of the far side of the Moon?
What Dutch city was repeatedly plundered by the Vikings?

This was the second NASA space project. It helped develop the techniques, that made the famous Apollo missions possible. This spacecraft, the most sophisticated of its time, was launched by a converted Titan 2 rocket.

Most people thought a flight to the Moon would be impossible. Many developments had to take place, before it could even be seriously considered. One such development was the launch of the first artificial satellite in space, by the Soviet Union. What was the satellites name?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Sputnik One

questions.question: In 1596, navigator Cornelis de Houtman set  foot on the shore of  what future colonial possession?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Dutch East Indies (Indonesia)

questions.question: The first Dutch railway opened in this year -- the same year Belgian independence was recognized by the Dutch.
According to a legend, what preacher was killed by pagans at the northern city of Dokkum in 754?
What Liberal statesman was Prime Minister of the Netherlands in the mid 19th century?  He drafted constitutional changes following the Paris Revolution of 1848.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Johan Rudolf Thorbecke

questions.question: Who was the second wife (1879) of King William the Third of Netherlands? Her only daughter, Wilhelmina ascended the throne on September 6th, 1898 at the age of eighteen.

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Disaster and Earth
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, rivals, bird. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: This disaster, which took place in 1883, caused a tsunami with up to 50 m high waves. It struck the coasts of Java and Sumatra, flooding approximately 300 towns and killing 36.000 people. What was the direct cause?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Explosion of Krakatau

questions.question: The famous rhyme I had a little bird. Its name was Enza. I opened the window. And In-flew-Enza refers to what disaster?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Spanish Flu

questions.question: Napoleon started his military career in the cavalry.
In the year 1770, the worst ever famine in history struck this region, considered to be one of the most densely populated areas on Earth.

This 1755 disaster was widely believed to be Gods wrath. After this disaster, the Inquisition came down even harder on the non-believers. In Spain and Portugal non-Catholics were forced to baptize, in England and Sweden official days of fasting were proclaimed. Voltaire mentioned this disaster in his Novel Candide.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Lisbon Earthquake

questions.question: In 79 BC, a major cloud appeared over mount Vesuvius. The eruption that would follow, would forever be linked to the demise of Pompeji. However, this was not the only city buried beneath ash and mud. What other town was devastated by the eruption?
The mission of Luna 24 was to collect soil samples from the Moon.

This was the first joint flight of the two rivals in the race to the Moon. It was also the first international manned spaceflight. A Soviet and an American spacecraft were joined to test the compatibility of their rendezvous and docking systems.
Napoleon Bonaparte usually wore a uniform of the following rank.

On October 24, 1960 a rocket exploded on a launchpad at Baikonur Cosmodrome and caused the death of over 100 military personnel, engineers, and technicians.  While once thought to have been space related, it later became known that the accident was connected with the development of a new Intercontinental Ballistic Missile. The incident was covered up by the Soviet government and did not emerge until the 1990s.   What is this incident known as?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Nedelin catastrophe

questions.question: The Apollo project suffered some serious setbacks. Apollo 13 was supposed to be the third manned mission to land on the Moon. However, when the spacecraft was 321,860 km (199,994.5 miles) away from the Earth, an accident took place. The mission was canceled and the crew returned to Earth, proving that the spacecraft was capable of dealing with major crisis. What was the cause of this accident.

options.text: Explosion of one of the oxygen tanks

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Explosion of one of the oxygen tanks

questions.question: This Mameluke was Napoleons constant attendant.
Napoleon Bonapartes body still lies in Saint Helena, where he was buried.
Napoleon Bonaparte had no children to succeed him.
This was Napoleons perfect battle.
